habitat_description: Found in aquatic habitats including cienegas, pools, springs, seeps, livestock tanks,wells, lakes, reservoirs, ponds, streams and rivers (Degenhardt et al., 1996, Stebbins 1985). There are 2 acknowledged forms, the rim form and the southeastern form (Degenhardt et al., 1996, Sredl and Jennings, 2003). Occurs 53% in lotic systems and 45% in stock tanks (Degenhardt et al., 1996).Most aquatic of all NM frogs (Degenhardt et al., 1996). Nocturnal and hides in vegetation surrounding aquatic habitat (Degenhardt et al., 1996). Populations may exhibit seasonal fluctuations in relative abundance (Degenhardt et al., 1996). Breed year round in thermal springs (Degenhardt et al., 1996). Egg masses have been found in February - September (Degenhardt et al., 1996). Tadpoles metamorphose in August and September. Activity increases as nocturnal water temperature increases (Degenhardt et al., 1996). Found in oak and mixed oak and pine woodlands and forests around streams with deep pools (Sredl and Jennings, 2003). Ranges into chaparral, grasslands and deserts as well (Stebbins, 1985). Prefers shallow water with emergent and perimeter vegetation and adult basking sites (Sredl and Jennings, 2003).   Lives < 6 years (Sredl and Jennings, 2003).
